{{Religious text primary|date=December 2010}} [[File:Golden plates and other artifacts.jpg|right|thumb|A 21st-century artistic representation of the [[golden plates]], [[Urim and Thummim]], [[Laban_(Book_of_Mormon)#Sword_of_Laban|Sword of Laban]], and [[Liahona (Book of Mormon)|Liahona]]]]
In the [[Latter Day Saint movement]], the '''Urim and Thummim''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|j|ʊər|ɪ|m|...|ˈ|θ|ʌ|m|ɪ|m}};<ref>[http://www.lds.org/scriptures/bofm/pronunciation?lang=eng LDS.org: "Book of Mormon Pronunciation Guide"] (retrieved 2012-02-25), [[Wikipedia:IPA for English|IPA]]-ified from «yūr´ĭm» and «thum´ĭm»</ref> also called '''Interpreters''') usually refers to a set of [[seer stone (Latter Day Saints)|seer stones]] bound by silver bows into a set of spectacles, that movement founder [[Joseph Smith]] said he found buried in the hill [[Cumorah]] with the [[golden plates]].
==History== Smith said that in 1823 an [[angel Moroni]] told him of the existence, with the plates, of "two stones in silver bows" fastened to a breastplate, which the angel called the [[Urim and Thummim]] and which he said God had prepared for translating the plates.<ref>[[Joseph Smith–History]] [http://scriptures.lds.org/en/js_h/1/34-35#34 1:34–35].</ref> Smith's mother, [[Lucy Mack Smith]], described them as crystal-like "two smooth three-cornered diamonds."<ref>{{cite book |last= Smith |first= Lucy Mack |authorlink = Lucy Mack Smith |title= [[The History of Joseph Smith by His Mother]] |year= 1853 |accessdate= 2006-02-02 |page= 101 }}</ref> [[Oliver Cowdery]] said the stones were "transparent".<ref>March 1831 letter of A.W.B. [Abram W. Benton], in ''Evangelical Magazine and Gospel Advocate'' (April 9, 1831) 2:120. (Concerning the 1830 trial of Smith in South Bainbridge, New York, Benton stated: "Oliver Cowdery, one of the three witnesses to the book, testified under oath, that said Smith found with the plates, from which he translated his book, two transparent stones, resembling glass, set in silver bows. That by looking through these, he was able to read in English, the reformed Egyptian characters, which were engraved on the plates".)</ref> Smith and his early Mormon contemporaries seem to have used the terms "[[seer stone (Latter Day Saints)|seer stone]]" and "Urim and Thummim" interchangeably.<ref name = ldstranslation>[http://www.lds.org/topics/book-of-mormon-translation "Book of Mormon Translation"], lds.org.</ref> Although Smith always referred to the [[Book of Mormon]] "interpreters" as the Urim and Thummim, he may or may not have intended to make a distinction between that device and the seer stones that he used in receiving revelations.<ref>[[Richard Van Wagoner]] and Steven Walker, "Joseph Smith: 'The Gift of Seeing," ''[[Dialogue: A Journal of Mormon Thought]]'' '''15''':2 (Summer 1982): 59–63.</ref> The LDS Church has suggested that Smith and his contemporaries "seem to have understood the term more as a descriptive category of instruments for obtaining divine revelations and less as the name of a specific instrument".<ref name = ldstranslation/>
[[File:Joseph Smith receiving golden plates.jpg|left|175px|thumb|An 1893 engraving of Joseph Smith receiving the [[Golden Plates]] and the [[Urim and Thummim]] from the [[angel Moroni]]. The [[sword of Laban]] is shown at the bottom.]] In 1827, Smith said that he had been visited again by the angel who had previously revealed the location of the golden plates, along with other items such as the Urim and Thummim, and that these objects were buried in a nearby hillside. Smith said that after translating the Book of Mormon, he returned the plates and the Urim and Thummim to the angel, whom he identified as the resurrected [[Moroni (Book of Mormon prophet)|Moroni]]. Smith reportedly told [[Orson Pratt]] that the Lord gave him the Urim and Thummim when he was an inexperienced translator but that as he grew in experience, he no longer needed such assistance.<ref>"Two Days' Meeting at Brigham City," ''[[Millennial Star]]'' '''36''' [1874]:498–99).</ref>
The [[Bible Dictionary (LDS Church)|LDS Bible Dictionary]] defines the ''Urim and Thummim'' as "an instrument prepared of God to assist man in obtaining [[Revelation (Latter Day Saints)|revelation]] from the Lord and in translating languages."<ref>"[http://lds.org/scriptures/bd/urim-and-thummim?lang=eng&letter=u Urim and Thummim]," ''Bible Dictionary''.</ref> In the Book of Mormon, the prophets [[Book of Ether|the Brother of Jared]] and [[Book of Mosiah|Mosiah]] both used devices called "interpreters" to receive revelation for their people, and the [[Doctrine and Covenants]] declares that these "interpreters" were the Urim and Thummim.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://scriptures.lds.org/dc/17/1#1|title=Doctrine and Covenants 17|website=scriptures.lds.org}}</ref>
==Beliefs== Latter Day Saints believe that the Urim and Thummim of Joseph Smith and the Book of Mormon were the functional equivalent of the [[Urim and Thummim]] mentioned in the Old Testament.<ref>There are seven references to the Urim and Thummim in the Masoretic Text (the basis of most English translations of the Old Testament): {{Bibleverse||Exodus|28:30|}}, {{Bibleverse||Leviticus|8:8|}}, {{Bibleverse||Numbers|27:21|}}, {{Bibleverse||Deuteronomy|33:8|}}, {{Bibleverse|1|Samuel|28:6|}}, {{Bibleverse||Ezra|2:63|}}, {{Bibleverse||Nehemiah|7:65|}}. The Septuagint version (the pre-Christian Greek translation of the Old Testament) and some English translations of {{Bibleverse|1|Samuel|14:41|}} also references them.</ref> It could be speculated that there were three different sets of Urim and Thummim: the one of the Old Testament (Exodus 28:30) and two mentioned in the Book of Mormon (one used by the [[Jaredites]] and the other by [[King Mosiah I|King Mosiah]]).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://lds.org/scriptures/bofm/mosiah/8?lang=eng|title=Mosiah 8|website=lds.org}}</ref> Another speculation that has been made is that the one used by Smith is the one originally possessed by the Jaredites.<ref>D&C 10:1</ref><ref>See [[Bruce R. McConkie]], ''[[Mormon Doctrine (book)|Mormon Doctrine]]'' (Salt Lake City: Bookcraft, 1966), pp. 818–19.</ref>
